title: You Don't Need to Pirate Software: Here's How I Find Affordable Alternatives
description: Software piracy is never the answer.
author: John Awa-abuon
excerpt: Software piracy is never the answer.
text: Quick Links Discounts and Student Deals Older Versions of Software Software can be expensive, but pirating it is risky and unnecessary. The good news? You don’t have to choose between breaking the bank or the law. These are the tips and tricks I use to find affordable, legal alternatives. When it comes to affordable software, open-source tools are a goldmine. These are programs developed by communities of passionate developers who make their work freely available to everyone. The best part? Many open-source tools are just as powerful as their paid counterparts. Take GIMP (GNU Image Manipulation Program), for example. It’s a free alternative to Adobe Photoshop with robust photo editing features. While it might have a steeper learning curve, it’s more than capable of handling everything from basic retouching to advanced graphic design. For office productivity, LibreOffice is a fantastic alternative to Microsoft Office. It includes a word processor, spreadsheet tool, presentation software, and more—all compatible with Microsoft’s file formats. And if you’re into video editing, DaVinci Resolve (although not entirely open-source) offers a free version packed with professional-grade features. A quick online search for "best open-source alternatives to [software name]" will likely yield software options you can try. Open-source tools often rely on community support rather than dedicated customer service. This means you might need to rely on forums, tutorials, or documentation if you run into issues. But for the price (free!), it’s hard to beat. 2 Freemium Options Danny Maiorca/MakeUseOf If open-source tools feel too DIY for your taste, freemium options might be the perfect middle ground. Freemium software offers a free version with basic features, while premium features are locked behind a paywall. This model lets you try before you buy, and for many users, the free tier is often all they need. A great example is Canva. Its free version is incredibly robust, but if you need advanced features like brand kits or premium templates, you can upgrade and get the benefits of Canva Pro for a reasonable fee. The key to freemium tools is to evaluate whether the free version meets your needs before committing to a paid plan. Often, you’ll find that the free tier is more than enough to get started. 3 Discounts and Student Deals If you’re set on using premium software but don’t want to pay full price, discounts and student deals can help. Many companies offer significant price reductions for students, educators, and even non-profit organizations. All it takes is a little research and sometimes proof of eligibility. Adobe Creative Cloud is a popular example. Normally, a subscription to Adobe’s suite of tools can cost upwards of $50 per month, but students and teachers can get the entire collection for just $19.99 per month. That includes Photoshop, Premiere Pro, Illustrator, and more. Similarly, Autodesk, the company behind tools like AutoCAD and Maya, offers free access to its software for students and educators. If you’re not a student, don’t worry—there are still plenty of ways to save. Websites like Stack Social and Humble Bundle frequently offer discounted software bundles, often including premium tools at a fraction of their retail price. Keep an eye out for seasonal sales. Black Friday and Cyber Monday and back-to-school periods are prime times to snag software at a discount. Companies often run promotions during these times, making it easier to afford tools like Microsoft Office or Final Cut Pro. 4 Subscription Services Subscription services have changed the way we access software. Instead of paying hundreds (or thousands) of dollars upfront for a single program, you can now pay a monthly or annual fee to access a suite of tools. This model makes premium software more affordable and ensures you always have the latest updates and features. The most well-known example is Adobe Creative Cloud. For a monthly fee, you get over 20 apps, including Photoshop, Premiere Pro, Illustrator, and After Effects. While the full suite can be pricey, Adobe offers individual app subscriptions starting at $20.99 a month, which is a great option if you only need one or two tools. Another example is Microsoft 365 (formerly Office 365). For around $70 per year, you get access to Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and other productivity tools, along with 1TB of OneDrive cloud storage. There’s even a family plan that lets you share the subscription with up to six people, making it a cost-effective choice for households. 5 Older Versions of Software Older software versions can come in handy if you’re on a tight budget and don’t need the latest bells and whistles. Many developers sell or even give away previous versions of their programs at a fraction of the cost of the newest release. These versions often have all the core features you need, even if they lack some of the cutting-edge updates. For example, Microsoft Office 2019 is still widely available for purchase, and it’s a one-time payment rather than a subscription. While it doesn’t include cloud-based features like Microsoft 365, it has all the core tools for word processing, spreadsheets, and presentations. Similarly, Adobe CS6 (the last version before Adobe switched to a subscription model) is still a viable option for creatives, though you’ll need to find it through third-party sellers since Adobe no longer supports it. When considering older versions, it’s important to check system compatibility. Some older software may not run on the latest operating systems, so make sure your computer meets the requirements. Additionally, be cautious about where you purchase these versions—stick to reputable sellers to avoid pirated or counterfeit software. Finding affordable software doesn’t mean resorting to piracy or settling for subpar tools. There are countless legal and budget-friendly options available. The key is to assess your needs and explore your options. Remember, the best tool is the one that works for you—not the one with the highest price tag. So, before you consider pirating software, take a moment to explore these alternatives. You might just discover a better, more ethical way to get the job done.

Software can be expensive, but pirating it is risky and unnecessary. The good news? You don’t have to choose between breaking the bank or the law. These are the tips and tricks I use to find affordable, legal alternatives.

When it comes to affordable software, open-source tools are a goldmine. These are programs developed by communities of passionate developers who make their work freely available to everyone. The best part? Many open-source tools are just as powerful as their paid counterparts.

Take GIMP (GNU Image Manipulation Program), for example. It’s a free alternative to Adobe Photoshop with robust photo editing features. While it might have a steeper learning curve, it’s more than capable of handling everything from basic retouching to advanced graphic design.

For office productivity, LibreOffice is a fantastic alternative to Microsoft Office. It includes a word processor, spreadsheet tool, presentation software, and more—all compatible with Microsoft’s file formats. And if you’re into video editing, DaVinci Resolve (although not entirely open-source) offers a free version packed with professional-grade features.

A quick online search for "best open-source alternatives to [software name]" will likely yield software options you can try.

Open-source tools often rely on community support rather than dedicated customer service. This means you might need to rely on forums, tutorials, or documentation if you run into issues. But for the price (free!), it’s hard to beat.

2 Freemium Options

If open-source tools feel too DIY for your taste, freemium options might be the perfect middle ground. Freemium software offers a free version with basic features, while premium features are locked behind a paywall. This model lets you try before you buy, and for many users, the free tier is often all they need.

A great example is Canva. Its free version is incredibly robust, but if you need advanced features like brand kits or premium templates, you can upgrade and get the benefits of Canva Pro for a reasonable fee.

The key to freemium tools is to evaluate whether the free version meets your needs before committing to a paid plan. Often, you’ll find that the free tier is more than enough to get started.

3 Discounts and Student Deals

If you’re set on using premium software but don’t want to pay full price, discounts and student deals can help. Many companies offer significant price reductions for students, educators, and even non-profit organizations. All it takes is a little research and sometimes proof of eligibility.

Adobe Creative Cloud is a popular example. Normally, a subscription to Adobe’s suite of tools can cost upwards of $50 per month, but students and teachers can get the entire collection for just $19.99 per month. That includes Photoshop, Premiere Pro, Illustrator, and more. Similarly, Autodesk, the company behind tools like AutoCAD and Maya, offers free access to its software for students and educators.

If you’re not a student, don’t worry—there are still plenty of ways to save. Websites like Stack Social and Humble Bundle frequently offer discounted software bundles, often including premium tools at a fraction of their retail price.

Keep an eye out for seasonal sales. Black Friday and Cyber Monday and back-to-school periods are prime times to snag software at a discount. Companies often run promotions during these times, making it easier to afford tools like Microsoft Office or Final Cut Pro.

4 Subscription Services

Subscription services have changed the way we access software. Instead of paying hundreds (or thousands) of dollars upfront for a single program, you can now pay a monthly or annual fee to access a suite of tools. This model makes premium software more affordable and ensures you always have the latest updates and features.

The most well-known example is Adobe Creative Cloud. For a monthly fee, you get over 20 apps, including Photoshop, Premiere Pro, Illustrator, and After Effects. While the full suite can be pricey, Adobe offers individual app subscriptions starting at $20.99 a month, which is a great option if you only need one or two tools.

Another example is Microsoft 365 (formerly Office 365). For around $70 per year, you get access to Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and other productivity tools, along with 1TB of OneDrive cloud storage. There’s even a family plan that lets you share the subscription with up to six people, making it a cost-effective choice for households.

5 Older Versions of Software

Older software versions can come in handy if you’re on a tight budget and don’t need the latest bells and whistles. Many developers sell or even give away previous versions of their programs at a fraction of the cost of the newest release. These versions often have all the core features you need, even if they lack some of the cutting-edge updates.

For example, Microsoft Office 2019 is still widely available for purchase, and it’s a one-time payment rather than a subscription. While it doesn’t include cloud-based features like Microsoft 365, it has all the core tools for word processing, spreadsheets, and presentations.

Similarly, Adobe CS6 (the last version before Adobe switched to a subscription model) is still a viable option for creatives, though you’ll need to find it through third-party sellers since Adobe no longer supports it.

When considering older versions, it’s important to check system compatibility. Some older software may not run on the latest operating systems, so make sure your computer meets the requirements. Additionally, be cautious about where you purchase these versions—stick to reputable sellers to avoid pirated or counterfeit software.

Finding affordable software doesn’t mean resorting to piracy or settling for subpar tools. There are countless legal and budget-friendly options available. The key is to assess your needs and explore your options. Remember, the best tool is the one that works for you—not the one with the highest price tag. So, before you consider pirating software, take a moment to explore these alternatives. You might just discover a better, more ethical way to get the job done.
